content: On a Point/Counter Point thread I noticed that OldMole hadn't posted since June 10, 2008 and as usual that got me to thinking of all the other rather interesting posters that are no longer here for one reason or another. So maybe we can find out a few details by asking around... Do you know anyone who is MIA at Military.com? In my case, I am wondering what happened to the Mole? I miss his level responses.

title: What ever happened to __________ ?

content: I haven't spoken with him about it, but have with many other posters who are no longer here and will remain nameless. A lot of people have lost interest, and have gotten tired of the banter with a lot of the more ideologically-oriented here. I'm losing interest, myself - getting more difficult to engage in an intelligent discussion. It would be nice to exchange posts with someone with whom I simply agree to disagree without a lot of the craziness here. I can explain my position on a given subject, and I have to deal with people who can't even understand what I'm talking about - and I don't think my English is that complicated. I started a thread (that got cut off for a reason I still don't understand), and asked a question about why no one had mentioned this very important story before me. The first response I get: Some guy told me that I, a 25-year veteran who raised his children in a military environment, "has no respect for uniformed members and their families." Now - how does one respond to something like that? And putting up with it isn't even a matter of being "thick-skinned", as such comments come from a place I have no desire to go. The word I'd use to characterize such things got me, strangely, put on warning. But it would have accurately described the quality of the post. There's just way too much of that. I can't stop anyone from coming here, so it's probably just better if I stopped doing it. There are other things to do. I once really enjoyed coming here, but that's dissipating.

title: What ever happened to __________ ?

content: I think there are too many categories in the "Hot Topics and Current Events" bundle. "In The News" has been polluted because people can't tell the difference between a news item and an op-ed, and the mods are missing a lot of that. "Point/Counterpoint" and "General Discussion" have become redundant because people post news items in both of those. There are lots of others that don't get much traffic. Look at the numbers of topics and posts, figure out which ones get the most use, and dump the rest. It'd be a lot easier to concentrate on the activity of a few well-used categories. Another thing that concerns me is the fact that the mods can stop being mods if they want to jump in the fray and add their personal comments. Moderators generally exist to keep a conversation/debate on topic and an even keel, encourage participants to elaborate on unclear points, and remain objective. Not to tick anyone off, but when a mod can stop being a mod, how can we reasonably expect them to maintain neutrality in a topic? Perhaps, if a person signs on to be a mod, they have to either refrain from posting in a given thread, or stop posting altogether. The job of a moderator is a very important one, and their actions (or lack thereof) determines the quality and integrity of a given thread, and from a strategic level, the site as a whole.

Perhaps, if a person signs on to be a mod, they have to either refrain from posting in a given thread, or stop posting altogether. The job of a moderator is a very important one, and their actions (or lack thereof) determines the quality and integrity of a given thread, and from a strategic level, the site as a whole.
reply: I think there are too many categories in the "Hot Topics and Current Events" bundle. "In The News" has been polluted because people can't tell the difference between a news item and an op-ed, and the mods are missing a lot of that. "Point/Counterpoint" and "General Discussion" have become redundant because people post news items in both of those. There are lots of others that don't get much traffic. Look at the numbers of topics and posts, figure out which ones get the most use, and dump the rest. It'd be a lot easier to concentrate on the activity of a few well-used categories. Another thing that concerns me is the fact that the mods can stop being mods if they want to jump in the fray and add their personal comments. Moderators generally exist to keep a conversation/debate on topic and an even keel, encourage participants to elaborate on unclear points, and remain objective. Not to tick anyone off, but when a mod can stop being a mod, how can we reasonably expect them to maintain neutrality in a topic? Perhaps, if a person signs on to be a mod, they have to either refrain from posting in a given thread, or stop posting altogether. The job of a moderator is a very important one, and their actions (or lack thereof) determines the quality and integrity of a given thread, and from a strategic level, the site as a whole.
